text:
OK, how about we
just get started? So welcome, everyone, to
CS330 for day one of this fall

quarter. It's a very strange
fall quarter. We'll start with introductions. So my name is Chelsea.

I am an assistant
professor here at Stanford. This is actually the start of
my second year at Stanford.

So it's been an interesting
first couple of years.

And I'll be the kind of main
instructor for the course. I'm really excited that we're
going to have Karol Hausman be
giving a few of the lectures. Karol completed his PhD at USC.

And he's done foundational work
in multi-task reinforcement learning, skill discovery,
and hierarchical reinforcement

learning. And having him give
some of the lectures will hopefully mix
things up a little bit so that you don't just see
my face and hear my voice.

So Karol, do you want
to introduce yourself? Sure. Thanks, Chelsea.

And hi, everybody. As Chelsea said,
my name is Karol. I will be giving a few lectures.

And I'm really
excited about this. I'm a research scientist
at the Google Brain.

So I'll also try to tell you a
little bit about how it works at Google and how you can
apply some of the things

that you'll learn in this class. And, yeah, I'm very
excited to be here. I'm looking forward to
our classes together.

The next thing I'd
like to acknowledge is that 2020 has obviously been
a really tough year so far.

And we're only about
here in the year. And it's going to
remain a tough year for the duration of the course.

I mean, pandemics, fire
season, social justice issues,

they're not going to
become resolved overnight. And there's really a
lot of important issues that are going on outside
of the course that

may kind of have your attention
for the entire quarter.

And I know that many of you may
be facing numerous challenges ranging from-- coming up from these
different issues going on

around the world. And I saw many, many
of those challenges

that students were having when
I was teaching in the spring. So above all else, above kind of
what's going on in this course,

I encourage you to really make
sure to take care of yourself and make sure that you're kind
of putting yourself over--

yourself and your health
over everything else. And I hope that
kind of overall--

I hope that this course will
be a more enjoyable break from everything else that's
going on in the world.

With that, what is
the plan for CS330?

OK, in addition to
the lectures, I'm hoping to incorporate some case
studies of important and timely

applications that I think
are relevant to the world that we're in today. So, for example, we're
going to be talking about

multi-objective learning in the
YouTube recommendation system, which obviously has
implications for how--

for not just the YouTube
recommendation system but also other recommender systems and--

which kind of may have really
societal impacts, whether it be political or otherwise.

I will also talk
about meta-learning for a few-shot land cover
classification, which is a relevant application in
the context of climate change

and so forth. And then we'll also talk about
few-shot learning and GPT-3,

which was a very recent paper
that came out and showed what things look like
when you really scale

meta-learning models to
large amounts of data and very large models. So here is a range
of the topics that

will be covered in the course. This ranges from multi-task
learning and transfer learning

to meta-learning
algorithms, to more advanced meta-learning topics,
including topics

such as meta-overfitting and
unsupervised meta-learning. And we'll also talk about how
this connects to hierarchical

Bayesian models. We'll then dive into how these
techniques can be combined

with techniques in
reinforcement learning when you're faced with
sequential decision making problems. This will include multi-task RL,
goal-conditioned RL, meta-RL,

and hierarchical RL. And lastly, we'll talk
about lifelong learning and some open
problems in the field.

OK, and emphasis will be on
deep learning techniques. And kind of the later six
lectures in the course

will be on-- in like this reinforcement
learning domain.

OK. Topics we won't cover. So we won't generally be
covering topics in AutoML,

including architecture search,
hyperparameter optimization, and learning optimizers. However, a lot of the underlying
techniques will be covered.

And so this should prepare
you to be able to read papers on these topics.

OK, so why study multi-task
learning and meta-learning? And to start with
this, I'm actually going to talk about a
little bit of my research

first and talk about why I
care about multi-task learning and meta-learning. And then I'll talk
about some other reasons

to care about multi-task
learning and meta-learning.

So in my lab, a lot of
the research that we do is studying how can
we enable agents

to learn a breadth of
skills in the real world. And when I say agents, I
mean actually real robots

in the world. Robots like this robot
that can put a red block

into a shaped sorting
cube, that can watch a video of a human doing
something and figure out

what to do and how to
do the task as well.

And also robots
that can figure out how to use tools to
accomplish tasks.

So these are examples of
some of the work that we've done on robots. And you might ask, well,
why work with robots?

It seems like robots are a
lot of work to deal with. I think the robots can teach
us things about intelligence

and what it means
to be intelligent. They're faced with
the real world, they have to be
able to generalize

across tasks, across objects,
and across environments for them to actually be
useful in human environments.

They need some form of
common sense understanding in order to do
well, and in order

to operate well
in the real world. And also supervision can't
be taken for granted. You don't really know exactly
what sort of supervision

we should be providing
to robots in contrast to other kind of
standard machine learning problems like
supervised learning problems.

So think of robotics as kind
of a really challenging problem that can motivate a
lot of kind of problems

in the realm of
artificial intelligence and to kind of talk
about how this connects to multi-task learning
and meta-learning,

I want to tell a bit of a story.  So I began my PhD
in around 2014.

I was a PhD student
at UC Berkeley. And at the start
of my PhD, there

was a project going
on that was trying to train a robot with
reinforcement learning to learn a task like this.

And in particular what
the robot is trying to do is it's trying to
figure out how to insert those wheels into
the toy airplane,

how to essentially assemble
the last part of the plane. And what's cool about
this is that the robot is

learning really from scratch. It didn't know what to do. And it's figuring out
through trial and error

how to eventually perform
this last step of the assembly process.

And so I thought
this is pretty cool. But there is a bit
of a catch, which is that the robot actually
had its eyes closed.

The robot wasn't
actually using its camera in any way to solve this task.

It was just blindly like
trying to figure out how to stick the
wheels into the plane.

And this motivated for me-- kind of the obvious
thing, the clear next step here was to try to
actually allow the robot

to learn these kinds of tasks
but also learn perception as a part of that.

And what we wanted
to do is we wanted to figure out how the robot
might learn a neural network

that maps from images taken
from the robot's camera to the torques applied
at the robot's joints.

And again, here the robot
is starting from scratch and is learning through
trial and error, how do you insert the red block
into the shape-sorting cube?

And it actually
needs to use vision to be able to see
where the shapes are, and the cube is in this case.

And over time, it learns and it
figures out how to do the task. When it figures out how
to do the task in a way

such that if I'm holding the
cube in front of the robot, you can also figure
out how to do that. And you can see the robot's
viewpoint right here.

So we were pretty
excited about this result that we could learn a neural
network end-to-end that could

solve this manipulation task. We were excited about it
not because the robot could put the red block into
the shape-sorting cube,

but because the robot had
a kind of a general purpose reinforcement learning
algorithm that allowed

it to solve a number of tasks. It could also learn how to
place the claw of the toy hammer underneath the nail.

It could figure out how to
screw a cap onto a bottle.

And with a similar
technique in follow-up work,

the robot could, whoops--
the robot could use a spatula to lift an object into a
bowl, although it looks

like this video isn't playing. But maybe you can
trust me that it's able to figure out how to use
the spatula with the object.

So this is pretty cool,
and a number of other works kind of built upon this
method, on their own robot to learn other tasks, like
hitting a puck into a goal,

opening a door, and throwing
an object to hit a target. And around the same time,
other folks at deep learning,

for example, were leveraging
some similar algorithms to play Atari games, to play
Go, to learn locomotion skills

and so forth. So we're pretty excited. But we had a bit of a problem
with these algorithms.

And the problem
was that the robot was learning this one task
and this one environment starting from scratch.

And if, for example, you gave
the robot a different spatula or a different bowl,
the robot wouldn't

be able to complete the task
and it would completely fail. And you'd have to
just train it again from scratch with that
spatula and that bowl

if you wanted it to succeed.  So this is a problem,
especially if you

care about building robots that
can do many different things and can be generally useful.

And you might also-- maybe we could just
give it more spatulas. But behind the
scenes, if you looked

at what the training
process looked like for many of these systems,
it looks something

like this, where the robot will
kind of hit the puck or attempt

to hit the puck into the goal. And then kind of a
human will come in and reset the puck position.

And maybe reset the
goal position too throughout the process. And one thing you might
notice in this video, this

is my friend Yevgen.
Yevgen is actually doing more work than the
robot is doing in this case.

This picture seems a
little bit backwards. And perhaps more
importantly, it's really not practical to
collect a lot of data this way.

And so if we want
to instead build more general-purpose
robots, we may

need to rethink
the way that we're collecting data and
training these methods,

or training these models.  So there's this issue that
they rely on detail supervision

and guidance. And this isn't just a
problem with reinforcement learning and robotics. It's also a problem arguably
with many other machine

learning systems as well. So while machine translation
systems and object detection

systems have been quite
successful at processing many different diverse
inputs, they're

still training one
task from scratch with very detailed supervision. And if you want that same
system to do many other things,

if you want it to
tell you a story, or if you want your object
detection system to also kind of tell you something
about oranges and bananas,

it isn't able to do that. So in this sense, I'd call all
of these systems specialist

AI systems in the
sense that they're doing really just a single task
often in a single environment.

And instead, a lot of-- my motivation for studying
more general algorithms

is looking at the way
that humans learn. So if you look at the
way that kind of humans learn much more general
skills and behaviors,

they learn by exploring a very
rich and diverse environment. They don't need a lot of
supervision in comparison

to the way that we train
supervised learning systems.

And they're able to learn
with a lot of autonomy. So in this sense, I would refer
to humans as more generalists.

We're able to do many
different things and leverage kind of very diverse
experiences in order to do so.

And so if you thought about
kind of something like AlphaGo, that analogous
kind of human thing

would be looking at taking
a baby tabula rasa who hasn't learned anything
yet and training

them to play Go from day one. And that's the analogy of what
kind of our current AI systems

look like. And if you think about this
kind of more critically, this seems really silly.

Perhaps we should
instead be thinking about how to actually
train these systems to do

much broader tasks and
learn much broader things about the world from day one.

OK. So that's a bit
about my research. And well, I'm pretty excited
about building more generalist

machine learning systems and
the topics in this course. And beyond robots and beyond
general-purpose machine

learning systems,
why else should we care about multi-task
learning and meta-learning?

And, first, I'll
talk about, well, why should we care
about deep learning? So kind of deep is in
the title of this course.

And so many of you probably
don't need too much motivation for using deep
learning, but there

are a few reasons why I care
a lot about deep learning. So if you go back to
the kind of mid-2000s,

so really the common technique
for solving computer vision problems was to hand
design features.

So people would use
something called like HOG or SIFT
or something else

to acquire some kind
of mid-level features. And then they would design
something else on top of that,

like a deformable parts model to
get some higher level features. And then they would train a
classifier on top of that.

So this is basically like how
everyone did computer vision back in the 2000s.

And then in 2012 and more
modern computer vision systems,

they basically take this
pipeline, which is first very hand-designed, each of
these kind of components, HOG and deformable part
models, each of those

need to be
hand-designed by a user. And it's also quite
brittle because if one part of the system doesn't
do what you expect, then

the other parts down the road
aren't able to handle that. So what modern computer
vision systems do

is they take this kind
of pipeline model, take a big neural network
and train this neural network end-to-end for the task of
predicting poses of people

or whatever you
want it to output.

So one of the things
that this does-- deep learning
essentially allows us to handle whatever inputs we
want, whether it be pixels,

language, sensor readings,
et cetera, rather than handling kind of a
low-dimensional process representation.

And as a result, it's a kind of
a very general-purpose toolbox for allowing us to process
a wide variety of inputs

without having to
hand-engineer features, without a ton of
domain knowledge about a particular area.

So this allows us to apply these
techniques much more broadly. And then, of course,
the second thing

is beyond having to
hand-engineer things and beyond the ability to
process many kinds of inputs.

Deep learning also
works really well. So this is the image
that competition results over the year
from 2011 to 2016.

And basically this point
right here is AlexNet.

Everything before this was
kind of hand-engineered models. And everything after this was
deep neural network models.

So we see this pretty
huge gap between the hand-engineered models
and the neural network models. And as when they're initially
introduced, and then

we also see, of course,
the continued improvement throughout the years after that.

And of course, it's not just
a thing in computer vision. If you look at machine
translation, for example,

in 2016, Google
introduced this paper that really made huge strides
in machine translation.

Basically what this is comparing
is a phrase-based machine translation system to a
machine translation system

based on neural networks. And you see these huge
gains if you look at--

they're looking at
human evaluation scores on a scale of 0 to 6. And you see these huge gains
from typically in the high-4

from the phrase-based system
to the mid-5 from the neural system and kind of a
relative improvement--

large relative improvements
across the board for all language pairs.

And really this is also
what's behind Google Translate that you use today.

OK, so that's kind
of an explanation

of why deep learning. What about multi-task
learning and meta-learning? So one thing that we've
learned from deep learning

is that if we take very large
and diverse data sets and use deep learning, combine
those with large models,

then we get-- the outcome of that is we get
very broad generalization.

We've seen this time and
time again with ImageNet, with transformer models,
with Google translation.

However, in many
different applications, we don't necessarily
have a large data set.

So in medical
imaging, for example, in robotics, and
personalized education, medicine,
recommendation systems,

when you want to translate
more rare languages, you often don't
have a huge data set for every robot or every
patient or every student.

And so these techniques
may not actually be that useful or applicable to
these very real world problems.

And so it's impractical to learn
from scratch for each disease, for each robot, for each
person, for each task.

And this is one
of the areas where multi-task learning
and meta-learning can come into play.

Beyond that, what if your
data has a long tail? So in many real-world
situations, we don't have these nice
Gaussian distributions

or something. We see this kind of very
long tail of the data where-- for some objects, we
see them all the time.

But for other objects, we only
see a few instances of them in the tail of
that distribution,

or maybe this is not obvious
encounters but interactions with different people or
words that we've heard, maybe some words we hear
all the time and some words

we don't hear all the
time, or driving situations and so forth. And this is a setting
that really breaks

the standard machine
learning paradigm, because once you're in
this part of the tail, then you really don't
see a lot of data.

Beyond that, what if you need
to quickly learn something new?

You want to learn
about a new person or you want to learn
for a new task or about a new environment. This is something that
also comes up all the time.

And so as an example of
this, I actually want to give all of you a
little, test, a quiz.

It won't be for a
grade or anything.

Here we go. So in particular, I'm going to
give you a training data set. Your training data
is on the left.

You have six data points. The three data points on the
left are paintings by Braque.

And the three data points on the
right are paintings by Cezanne.

And your goal is, given
this training data, can you classify which painter
painted the right data point?

And I'm going to do
this with a poll. So I'll give you a minute
to think about this

and try to figure out if this
kind of image on the right was painted by
Braque or by Cezanne.

And then you could enter what
you think in the poll on Zoom.
Can everyone see the poll?

It is by one of
these two painters. It's not a trick question. It's also about a deepfake.

Great, so 77% Braque. That's the correct
answer, which is good. Most of you are very
good few-shot learners.

And if you're curious, the
way that you can see this is that you can see all sorts
of lines in the Braque drawings.

And you also see
some of those lines, some of those more geometric
shapes in the test datapoint

as well. OK, so this is exactly
what few-shot learning is where you're given
a very tiny data set

and you want to be able to make
a prediction based on that data set. How do you accomplish this?

Well, if you trained a machine
learning system from scratch on these just six data
points, it would probably

do pretty abysmally. And so what's different is
that you have prior experience.

You're not learning
completely from scratch. And while you may not have
seen these particular paintings before or maybe you haven't even
seen paintings from these two

painters before, you
have prior experience of the styles of different
painters or maybe just

generally prior experience
of looking at images. And this allows you--
these sorts of priors about the world allow
you to solve this task.

OK, so really for all
these reasons laid out. If you want a more
general-purpose system,

if you don't have a large data
set, if you have a long tail distribution, or if you want
to quickly learn something new,

these are all elements of
where multi-task learning and meta-learning
can come into play.
Cool. So what is a task?

For now, it also, what
is multi-task learning? So for now, a task is going
to be a dataset and a loss

function where you want
to produce a model. So your task is given a
dataset and a loss function,

you want to produce a
model that does well, that minimizes that loss
function on that dataset.

And different tasks
can vary based off of different objects,
different people.

Maybe you have different
objective functions or maybe you have different
lighting conditions. You want to be able to classify
objects and different lighting

conditions. Maybe different tasks
correspond to different words, or translating between different
languages and so forth.

So the definition of a task
that we'll use in this class is a lot broader than the kind
of semantic meaning of task.

They can vary really in all
of these different ways.

So that's something to keep
in mind throughout the course, one really critical assumption
that we're going to make

is that different tasks need to
share some amount of structure.

If they don't hold
any structure at all, then you're going to be better
off using single-task learning.

But the good news
is that there are many tasks with some
amount of shared structure.

So here are a couple
of pictures of me doing some object manipulation
tasks, in particular

I'm trying to open
the lid of a jar or open the cap of a water
bottle or grind some pepper.

And in each of these
cases, while they may seem very different from
a semantic point of view,

the actual physical motion of
these tasks is very similar.

And even if these tasks
are seemingly on-- even if the set of tasks that you
have are seemingly unrelated,

we do know that
the laws of physics underlie all of the
real data that we have. We also know that people are
all organisms with intentions.

The rules of English underlie
all English language data. You know that languages are all
developed for similar purposes

and so forth. And these kind of underlying
rules and underlying intentions leads to far greater
structure than simply

having completely random tasks.  OK, so some informal
problem definitions,

and we'll define these a little
bit more formally next time.  First, the multi-task
learning problem

that we'll be talking
about is to try to learn a set of tasks more
quickly or more proficiently

than learning each of
them independently. And the meta-learning
problem statement will be given data or experience
on a set of previous tasks,

so you want to learn a new
task more quickly and/or more proficiently.

So these are going to be
the two central problem statements that we're going to
be looking at in this course.

And we'll be looking at a range
of methods that solve these two problem statements.

And they may not be
multi-task learning algorithms or meta-learning
algorithms, per se. There's also other algorithms
like transfer learning,

for example, that can solve the
second problem to some degree and we'll be covering some of
those algorithms in this course

as well. These are the
problem statements. And then yeah, the
individual algorithms
may be more specific.  Great.

Now one thing you
might be wondering is, doesn't multi-task
learning just kind of

reduce to single-task learning? In particular, what if you
just took all of your datasets

for each of your tasks and
took the union of them and set your loss function to be the sum
of all of your individual task

loss functions? So in this sense,
well, maybe we're just done with the course.

We just kind of take this,
take the union over datasets, take the sum of
our loss functions, and then apply standard machine
learning to our problem.

And we're done with
multi-task learning.

In many ways, this is right. Yes, you can reduce it
to single-task learning.

And aggregating the
data across tasks and learning a single model
is one successful approach

to multi-task learning. But we can often also do better. We can often exploit
the fact that we

know that this data is
coming from different tasks and use that to develop
better algorithms.

OK, so there are some
questions in the chat.

Let's start with-- let's
start with the question from--

would transfer learning
fall under the umbrella of meta-learning? So when I talked about the
problem statements before,

these are very general
problem statements. And in the
meta-learning problem, for example, I'll call this
the meta-learning problem

but there are kind of
a range of techniques that solve this problem,
including transfer learning techniques and
meta-learning techniques.

So there is a distinction
between meta-learning and transfer learning. One way that I'd like to
think about the distinction

is that meta-learning
algorithms are explicitly optimizing for effective
transfer with a certain amount

of data whereas transfer
learning methods tend to actually hand-design
techniques that

lead to good transfer rather
than explicitly optimizing for good transfer
with a set of tasks.

[AUDIO OUT] is asking what
is the main difference between multi-task
learning and meta-learning? Is it that in
meta-learning, you're

training from scratch
on all the tasks? And the main thing
that is different is that in
meta-learning you often

want to try to solve a new
task more quickly or more proficiently, given kind
of previous experience,

whereas in multi-task
learning, you're kind of given a set of tasks and
you want to do well on all of these tasks
at the same time.

One approach to the
meta-learning problem, may be to basically
just take this new task and add this to the
task data that you

had before and then apply a
multi-task learning algorithm. One thing that's a bit
different in meta-learning

is that typically we
assume that after we've trained on these
previous tasks, we're not going to revisit all
that data and experience.

We're just going to
try to apply what we've learned to a new task,
basically essentially compile all of this previous
experience into a single model

or into a single
set of parameters, and then use that
compiled experience when

learning a new task.  [AUDIO OUT] is asking, why
not a weighted sum here?

You could definitely also have
a weighted sum in problems where that may make sense. And we'll get into some of
the more details of that

in the next lecture.  And then there's
also a question,

would self-supervised learning
be a subset or superset of meta-learning?

I think it depends
on the application. I would say both. I think that in
some situations, it may be considered a subset
and some conditions that

may be considered a superset. I think it kind
of-- yeah, it really depends on what sort of
application you have in mind.

Lots more questions. So is model-agnostic
meta-learning

for fast adaptation
of deep networks also an approach to this
meta-learning problem in parallel with RL approaches?

So, yes, the model-agnostic
meta-learning algorithm is attempting to kind of address
the meta-learning problem.

And [AUDIO OUT] would
like me to reiterate

on the differences
between transfer learning and meta-learning. So we'll talk about
this a bit more later.

But in my mind, kind
of the key difference is that in transfer
learning-- well,

there are a few differences. So in transfer learning,
you often design something.

You often take some
prior experience and design some rule to transfer
what you've learned previously

to a new task. So one way to do this is
fine tuning where you take a model trained on previous
tasks, and then fine

tune it for a new task. This is kind of a hand-designed
scheme to transfer knowledge

after seeing a small amount
of data for a new task. So this is one of the
more salient differences
between the two.

Cool. And then there is also a
question, what about online

learning or training
at test time? Is that similar in
concept to meta-learning?

Any key differences? We'll talk about online
learning and lifelong learning

later in the course. And there are actually a lot
of synergies between the two. There are actually methods
that apply meta-learning

for the problem of when you
receive a stream of tasks or a stream of data points. And we'll talk about
that later in the course.

OK, so those were I
think all the questions.

Why now? So why should we study
multi-task learning and meta-learning now? So it turns out
people were actually

thinking about a
lot of these ideas back in the 1990s,
a long time ago.

So, for example, this is
a paper by Rich Caruana where he was looking at--

he's basically thinking
about training tasks in parallel using a
shared representation,

saying that kind of, you want
to do multi-task inductive transfer and add extra
tasks and extra outputs

to a back propagation
net, so he's also thinking about this in the
context of neural networks. In 1998, Sebastian Thrun, who
was formerly a professor here,

was thinking about how humans
can generalize correctly even from a single-training
example just

like the few-shot learning
tasks that you did earlier. And when faced with
a new thing to learn, humans can usually exploit an
enormous amount of training

data and new experiences
that stem from other related learning tasks.

Further, Sami Bengio
in 1992 was thinking about the possibility
for a learning role that

could learn to solve new tasks. So in all of these
cases, people were thinking about the problems
of multi-task learning

and meta-learning
many, many years ago. So why should we
care about it now?

And why is it
quite relevant now? So these algorithms
are really continuing to play a fundamental role
in machine learning research.

For example, in natural
language processing, people have looked at
multilingual machine translation training for
language translation across 102

languages, and surpassing
strong prior methods. People have also been looking
at text-to-text transformers,

training a multi-task
model that could solve all of these different
tasks at once, including summarization,
question-answering,

and so forth. In robotics, we've done some
work on one-shot imitation learning where you want to
be able to learn a new task,

in this case placing an
object into a red bowl from a single video of a human.

So we'll talk about how this
works later in the course.

And also people have
looked at trying to train across multiple
different domains and simulation in order to
transfer to the real world.

So this is a paper from 2017
from Fereshteh Sadeghi that looked at training across
lots of different environments

in simulation. And then ultimately transferring
this to a real quadcopter in the real world.

And beyond MLP and
robotics, people looked at this in a range
of other domains as well. So here's another example--

actually a case study that we'll
talk about in the next lecture where researchers at Google
are looking at using multiple--

optimizing multiple objectives
in a YouTube recommendation system.

Beyond those papers, I think
that these algorithms are also playing an increasing role
in machine learning research.

It's a bit difficult to study
how many papers are using a kind of particular technique.

But if you look at Google Search
queries for multi-task learning and meta-learning, you'd see
an increase-- a pretty big

increase from 2015 to 2020. Also if you look at citations,
this isn't a perfect measure

but if you look at
citations for papers in transfer learning,
meta-learning, and multi-task learning, there's
also a pretty big increase

suggesting that more
people are looking at these kinds of algorithms
and trying to apply them to different domains.

And then lastly, I think that
the success of these algorithms will be critical for
the democratization

of deep learning. So as I mentioned before,
deep neural networks require a massive
amount of data in order

to successfully learn tasks. If you look at some of
the most common data sets

in computer vision and
natural language processing and in speech, these data
sets have 1.2 million images

and labels, 40 million
paired sentences, 300 hours of labeled data.

And in contrast, if you look
at some examples of real world problems, such as a diabetic
retinopathy detection dataset,

this has 35,000 labeled images. If you look at an epilepsy
treatment paper that

was looking at using
reinforcement learning, that had less than
an hour of data. And in some of the
work that we've

done with learning for
robotic manipulation, if we want to train a
robot to do a new task, we may only have around
15 minutes of data.

So we need to think
about how we might move past single-task
large scale supervised

learning, if we really
want to solve some of these real-world problems.

Beyond the kind of
exciting research that has been happening
in the past several years,

that we'll talk
about in this course, there's also still many, many
open questions and challenges.

I think that this makes this
topic, especially exciting from a research
point of view because

of all of these open
questions and challenges. And in some ways, this
is a bit of a disclaimer that a lot of the
things that we'll

be talking about in this course
are still being developed in the law of the ideas
that we'll be talking about are really at the forefront
of where the research is.

OK, so any questions
to wrap things up?

So there's a question
from [AUDIO OUT] saying

that for multi-task
learning to work, the tasks need to be
similar, is this the case for meta-learning as well?

Yeah, and this is the case. So if the tasks--
well, and I guess I'll qualify that a little bit.

They need to share some
amount of structure. They don't need to necessarily
be extremely similar. They just need to have some
shared structure, something

that they share, that
the algorithm can latch onto in order to
learn more quickly

or to learn more efficiently
than learning completely from scratch. So this is an
important assumption

that underlies all
of these algorithms.
OK, great.

[AUDIO OUT] is also
asking, is there a way to quantitatively measure
how similar two tasks are,

in general settings
and in reinforcement learning settings? So there's actually very little
work on measuring similarity.

And it's also a really
difficult problem

because if you want to measure
the similarity of two tasks, in many ways depends not only
on the tasks, the datasets

and the loss functions,
but it may also depend on your current
representation, what

you've learned about in
the world and so forth. So for example, if
you know how to grasp
objects, then a task of--

two tasks that kind of
involve grasping objects, they appear more
similar than otherwise.

And also if you don't
know how to grasp objects, then it may be more difficult
to recognize some of the shared

structure between other tasks. It also kind of
depends on what you want to learn from
something as well.

So if you want to
learn the problem of,

what's a good example? Writing. If you want to learn how to
write different characters

or something, then the thing
that all those tasks share is being like holding
a pen in a certain way.

And so if you
haven't yet learned how to hold a pen
in a certain way then those tasks may
share a lot of structure

because you first need
to learn that to learn both of those tasks. But after you've learned how
to hold the pen in that way,

then those tasks may
appear less similar because the new thing
that you need to learn is very different
for the two tasks.

So this is one thing that makes
basically quite challenging

to understand the
difference between two tasks because it also depends on
your current representation in your current model.

So another person is asking,
do all camera-based perception

algorithms fall
under similar tasks and can be solved using
multi-task learning and meta-learning?

A lot of the multi-task learning
benchmarks in the computer vision domain do look actually
a lot like this where you're training a single
model to segment

and detect and predict
surface normals and so forth. So, yes, that's kind of the
short answer to that question.
